articles.headline: Obama to Veto Bill That Could Speed Foreclosures
articles.snippet: The little-noted measure suddenly gained attention amid questions about some big lenders’ slipshod bookkeeping.
articles.abstract: The little-noted measure suddenly gained attention amid questions about some big lenders’ slipshod bookkeeping.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As slipshod bookkeeping by some big mortgage lenders continued to rattle the housing market on Thursday, another major lender indicated it would suspend sales of foreclosed homes and White House officials said President Obama would not sign a bill that critics suggested could facilitate foreclosure fraud.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: While Europe Scrimps, European Union Spends
articles.snippet: Amid an austerity drive unparalleled in modern Europe, the bureaucracy that runs the bloc is haggling over how much to increase next year's budget.
articles.abstract: Amid an austerity drive unparalleled in modern Europe, the bureaucracy that runs the bloc is haggling over how much to increase next year's budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — In Greece, taxes are up and so is the age of retirement. In Spain, civil servants have taken pay cuts. In Britain, spending on welfare, the military and education could be chopped by a quarter.

articles.headline: G.M.’s Wage-Cutting Deal Clears Way for a Small Car
articles.snippet: Under a cost-saving arrangement, G.M. will pay 60 percent of the plant’s 1,550 workers the going wage of $28 an hour, and the remainder of the workers about half as much — or $14 an hour.
articles.abstract: Under a cost-saving arrangement, G.M. will pay 60 percent of the plant’s 1,550 workers the going wage of $28 an hour, and the remainder of the workers about half as much — or $14 an hour.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORION TOWNSHIP, Mich.  General Motors is trying to do what no other automaker has accomplished before  make money on a low-price subcompact car built in the United States with unionized labor.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: First Buyers of Nissan Leaf Get a Trunkful of Perks
articles.snippet: Buyers of the first all-electric car receive tax credits, rebates, a charging unit and, in some areas, free parking.
articles.abstract: Buyers of the first all-electric car receive tax credits, rebates, a charging unit and, in some areas, free parking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tax credits, rebate checks, personalized home visits, government giveaways  even customer service calls from top corporate executives.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Chief Steps Into Dispute Over China’s Currency Policy
articles.snippet: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, managing director of the I.M.F., urged China to allow its currency to rise in value as a way to ease tensions between Beijing and Washington.
articles.abstract: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, managing director of the I.M.F., urged China to allow its currency to rise in value as a way to ease tensions between Beijing and Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The head of the International Monetary Fund urged China on Thursday to allow its currency to rise in value, an attempt to keep a contentious issue between the United States and China from broadening into a bitter international dispute.

articles.headline: Afghans Linked to the Taliban Guard U.S. Bases
articles.snippet: The Pentagon’s oversight of the Afghan guards is virtually nonexistent, a Senate inquiry found.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon’s oversight of the Afghan guards is virtually nonexistent, a Senate inquiry found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Afghan private security forces with ties to the Taliban, criminal networks and Iranian intelligence have been hired to guard American military bases in Afghanistan, exposing United States soldiers to surprise attack and confounding the fight against insurgents, according to a Senate investigation.

articles.headline: Junk Bonds Are Back on Top
articles.snippet: Companies with less-than-sterling credit are rushing to sell bonds and take advantage of low interest rates.
articles.abstract: Companies with less-than-sterling credit are rushing to sell bonds and take advantage of low interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Casey remembers the fast times when Michael R. Milken ruled Wall Street as the billionaire king of junk bonds.

articles.headline: Picture Books No Longer a Staple for Children
articles.snippet: Publishers are scaling back on picture books as more parents favor text-heavy chapter books for their young children.
articles.abstract: Publishers are scaling back on picture books as more parents favor text-heavy chapter books for their young children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Picture books are so unpopular these days at the Children’s Book Shop in Brookline, Mass., that employees there are used to placing new copies on the shelves, watching them languish and then returning them to the publisher.

articles.headline: Flawed Foreclosure Documents Thwart Home Sales
articles.snippet: The shoddy preparation of foreclosure documents is hammering the market, especially in the worst-hit states.
articles.abstract: The shoddy preparation of foreclosure documents is hammering the market, especially in the worst-hit states.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCALA, Fla.  Amanda Ducksworth was supposed to move in to her new home this week, a three-bedroom steal here in central Florida with a horse farm across the road. Instead, she is camped out with her 7-year-old son at her boss’s house.
articles.byline: By Andrew Martin and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Nobel Peace Prize Given to Jailed Chinese Dissident
articles.snippet: In awarding the prize to Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Committee delivered a stinging rebuke of China’s growing intolerance for domestic dissent.
articles.abstract: In awarding the prize to Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Committee delivered a stinging rebuke of China’s growing intolerance for domestic dissent.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Liu Xiaobo, an impassioned literary critic, political essayist and democracy advocate repeatedly jailed by the Chinese government for his activism, has won the 2010 Nobel Peace Prize in recognition of “his long and non-violent struggle for fundamental human rights in China.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: Faith in Fed Pushes Dow Past 11,000
articles.snippet: Traders looked beyond the struggling jobs market report to the prospect of greater quantitative easing from the Fed.
articles.abstract: Traders looked beyond the struggling jobs market report to the prospect of greater quantitative easing from the Fed.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economy is looking down, why is the stock market looking up?

articles.headline: Public Jobs Drop Amid Slowdown in Private Hiring
articles.snippet: The United States economy lost 95,000 nonfarm jobs in September, the result of a decline in government jobs at all levels.
articles.abstract: The United States economy lost 95,000 nonfarm jobs in September, the result of a decline in government jobs at all levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the one-two punch long feared by many economists, hiring by businesses has slowed while government jobs are disappearing at a record pace.

articles.headline: Largest U.S. Bank Halts Foreclosures in All States
articles.snippet: The action by Bank of America is likely to increase pressure on lenders to declare their own moratoriums.
articles.abstract: The action by Bank of America is likely to increase pressure on lenders to declare their own moratoriums.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America, the nation’s largest bank, said Friday that it was extending its suspension of foreclosures to all 50 states.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Nelson D. Schwartz
